Intro 
This is Battery Indicator Pro, the "pro" version of the popular free app, Battery Indicator. It's available from the Android Market for US$0.99, but it's an open source project, which means you can download the source for free from the project website.


Summary 
Battery Indicator is a small, simple application for the Android mobile operating system. It's simply a little icon that lives in the status bar and shows you the percentage of battery charge left.


Limitations 
(These are out of my control.) 
• The app can only display what the phone tells it. Most phones report every 1%, but a few (notably the Motorola Droid) only report every 10%. 
• There's no way to remove the built-in battery icon.


Features 
• Small, simple, and easy to read. 
• It doesn't do any polling. It receives a broadcast message from the OS when the battery status changes, then it simply updates the icon and goes back to sleep. What this means is that it will take up a small amount of RAM, but essentially 0 CPU cycles, so it can't drain your battery. 
• Automatically starts when the phone boots up if it was running when the phone shut down.


Pro-only Features 
• High-resolution images (on devices that support them). 
• Easy access to Battery Use screen (requires Android 1.6+). 
• Configure to use Fahrenheit or Celsius as the battery temperature unit. 
• Configure to always start on boot, never start on boot, or start on boot if the app was running on shutdown. 
• Configure the icon to turn red below a configurable threshold and/or turn green above a configurable threshold. 
• The satisfaction of supporting the developer.

The settings are organized into three separate pages, as described below. Each page has its own help page describing the settings on that page. Simply press MENU->Help to get help from whatever settings page you are on.
Control icon colors and window themes
You can change the theme for the main window and control if and when the notification icon changes color.

Here you can control when the notification switches from saying exactly when the phone\'s status changed (unplugged, for example) to stating approximately how many hours ago the change happened.\n
\nYou can also control which estimates you want to see for the time remaining for USB/AC charging and light/normal/heavy/constant usage, and adjust the basis for these estimates.
All other settings are on this page, including logging, lock screen, temperature unit, autostart, and more.

Sets the theme for the main window. By default, the theme will roughly match a standard Android dialog, like Battery Indicator always has. The Full Window theme is useful if you like things big and easy to read. Other themes are just for fun.
If enabled, Battery Indicator will log battery state changes (e.g., the phone is unplugged or becomes fully charged).

If enabled, Battery Indicator will also log every change in the charge level, as well (e.g., going from 57% to 56% or vice versa). Most users probably have no need for this, but you can turn it on if you really want to keep an eye on things. Keep in mind that doing so will come with a slight performance hit.

Android allows apps to disable and reenable what it calls the \"keyguard\", which you probably think of as the lock screen. Beyond simply disabling and reenabling it, however, there is no more control — I can\'t control which keys turn the screen on, for example.
Confirm when manually disabling lock screen?

If checked, a confirmation dialog will pop up when you try to manually disable the lock screen. This is primarily intended to prevent new users from accidentally disabling their lock screen without knowing it. If you disable the lock screen with any regularity, you\'ll probably want to turn this off.
Exit main window immediately after dis/reenabling?

If you\'re someone for whom every keystroke (or touchscreen press) matters, you\'ll probably want to enable this. If your goal is to simply disable or reenable the lock screen and then get back to what you\'re doing, this keeps you from having to press the BACK key. Just pull down the notification bar, press on Battery Indicator, and press the button to toggle the lock screen: three screen presses and you\'re back to what you were doing.\n
\nFor obvious reasons, you can only enable this if the previous setting is disabled, and vice versa.
Disable the lock screen when charging?
If checked, then whenever the device is plugged in, Battery Indicator with disable the lock screen, and whenever the device is unplugged, it will enable it again.
Android reports the battery temperature in degrees Celsius. If you prefer to see the battery temperature in degrees Fahrenheit, check this option, and the app will convert for you.
Start Battery Indicator When Device Boots?

Controls whether Battery Indicator should start itself automatically when the device boots up.\n
\nThe \"If Running on Shutdown\" option works with regard to whether you\'ve most recently manually started or stopped Battery Indicator. So if you kill Battery Indicator through some other means, like a task killer, then Battery Indicator doesn\'t know you stopped it, and it will still start at boot up if you have it set to this.
Show the charge level as larger text next to icon?

I\'ve had a few users with poorer eyesight ask me to add this option, whereby the charge level is displayed as text (which is a bit larger and easier to read) right next to the icon when you pull down the notification area. The actual icon won\'t be any different, so this will only help when you pull down the notification tray, but it\'s better than nothing, and easy enough to add for those that want it.\n
\nTo save precious space, I\'ve done this in a very unglamorous fashion, simply plopping the number in there and carrying on. This turns out to be easier to read than if I included the percent symbol, and means that the text should all fit. It is possible that if you have a particularly small device, enabling this might make the AM/PM at the far right not quite fit.
Start Approximating Hours Since Status Change

Determines when the notification switches from saying, e.g., \"Unplugged Since 1:10 PM\" to saying something like \"Unplugged for 1 Hour\". The first way is more accurate, because it tells you exactly (to the minute) when the status changed, but many people prefer the simpler to comprehend approximation of the number of elapsed hours, so they make that happen sooner than the default of 12 hours.
Show charge time remaining while charging?
USB Charge Time From 0% to 100% in Hours

In order to keep the binary package for Battery Indicator reasonably small, there are some limitations for the colors. At the time of writing, you can have a red icon as high as 30%, an amber icon as high as 50%, and a green icon as low as 20%. I think these are reasonable compromises that should work for 99% of users.\n
\nTo give you maximum control, the colors can be turned on or off independently. This means that you can have as much as a four-tiered color scheme, where the icon is green when it is very full, then grayscale, then amber, then red. Of course, most people probably have the amber and green thresholds set to the same value, so that the icon is never grayscale.

The color preview will hopefully make it really easy to visualize what effect your color settings will have.\n
\nThis doesn\'t exist in 10% mode, because it just wouldn\'t make sense.
Use red icon when charge is low?
Whether or not to use a red icon below the specified threshold.
Red Icon Below What Charge Percentage?
Red Icon At or Below What Charge Percentage?

Specifies the charge level which the icon should turn red below (or at, in 10% Mode).


The options for the red threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are red icons available.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.
Use amber icon when charge is medium?
Whether or not to use an amber icon below the specified threshold.
Amber Icon Below What Charge Percentage?
Amber Icon At or Below What Charge Percentage?

Specifies the charge level which the icon should turn amber below (or at, in 10% Mode).


The options for the amber threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are amber icons available, starting 5 percentage points above the red threshold (if there is one). For example, if you have the red threshold set to 15, then your lowest option here will be 20.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.
Use green icon when charge is high?
Whether or not to use a green icon at or above the specified threshold.
Green Icon At or Above What Charge Percentage?

Specifies the charge level which the icon should be green at or above.


The options for the green threshold include all the values (in multiples of 5) for which there are green icons available, starting at the highest active threshold you have set for red or amber. For example, if you have the amber threshold set to 40, then your lowest option here will be 40.


In 10% Mode, things work slightly differently but should be self-explanatory.

Note: Checking or unchecking this will reset your icon color settings!


This setting cleans up the Icon Color settings to make more sense on devices that only show their charge level in 10% increments. According to user reports, that includes these devices:


• Motorola Droid (original) 
• Motorola Droid X 
• Motorola Droid 2 
• Samsung Moment


As far as I'm aware, all other devices report every 1%, and so should not turn this on.
